body:
to add : we just updated the mitmproxy docker image to 11.1.2 and suddenly got this :

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/861e4ab7-8fd8-4a93-98d6-07d9523e1d81)

but copy/pasting the token from the container log just sends us into a loop, the token is never accepted...

pinned it at 11.0.2 for now, that fixes it for us

refs https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/discussions/7544, but let's continue here.

Two questions for you folks:

1. What's your use case? Why does the default token generation or setting a fixed password not work for you? Access the the web UI is pretty much RCE, so I'm hesitant to provide an option that disables authentication.
2. @peterpeppered: Could you please share repro steps? What do you see in your browser logs, what do you see in your mitmproxy logs?

usecase is using the default mitmproxy container in a local dev stack with multiple other containers (for local development). current compose :
```
    mitmproxy:
        image: mitmproxy/mitmproxy
        container_name: mitmproxy
        volumes:
            - ./docker/mitmproxy:/home/mitmproxy/.mitmproxy
        ports:
            - "8081:8081"
            - "8080"
        command: mitmweb --web-host 0.0.0.0
        networks:
            - traefik
```
after this is started, the webinterface shows me the dialog to paste a token, but the `docker logs <container-id>` shows things like :
```
[12:08:15.313] HTTP(S) proxy listening at *:8080. [12:08:15.315] Web server listening at http://0.0.0.0:8081/?token=759070597a73fcb7d1470f25b1f9f39f [12:08:15.350] No web browser found. Please open a browser and point it to http://0.0.0.0:8081/?token=759070597a73fcb7d1470f25b1f9f39f
```
but... come to think of it, this output seems to only appear after stopping the container, so I guess the token I'm seeing is from the previous run, and hence invalid ? hmmm

...

just tried again, and it seems I'm indeed seeing old logs. I have no idea how to get a current token then.
to add : we did not change anything in the configuration, it always 'just worked' without the need for a token

okay, so it seems there's no option to get the old behaviour (i.e. unauthorized), and I can't seem to get at the current token from the container. however, doing this :
```
command: mitmweb --web-host 0.0.0.0 --set web_password='mitm' 
```
in `docker-compose.yml` seems to give us a default pasword to use. I guess that is fine for our use case :)

a web password is good for this kind of sensitive application.

would love to see a way to forcefully disable password requirement, or whitelisting localhost may also be another option.

> whitelisting localhost may also be another option.

that would be a nice solution I suppose, but not sure whether that helps with the RCE thing, which I suppose is related to https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/security/advisories/GHSA-wg33-5h85-7q5p

Another option I use now for anyone interested is passing the password in the url as a `token` query param.
So running mitm with:
```
mitmweb --web-host 0.0.0.0 --set web_password='mitm'
```
you should be able to open http://localhost:8081?token=mitm after authentication.
I will close this issue now. Thanks for the info!

> that would be a nice solution I suppose, but not sure whether that helps with the RCE thing, which I suppose is related to [GHSA-wg33-5h85-7q5p](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/security/advisories/GHSA-wg33-5h85-7q5p)

This is precisely the reason why we unfortunately had to implement a breaking change here. I'm sorry that this breaks people's setups during upgrade, but we can't keep the default configuration without a password in the light of this finding. Allowlisting localhost - which is kind of how it worked before - can be circumvented.

I'm not opposed to adding an option that disables authentication if we have a good use case for it that cannot be satisfied by adding `?token=password` to the URL. Apart from that, I will take the feedback here to add a better logging message that points to setting `web_password` manually.

issue.title: mitmweb: recommend setting `web_password` for systems without browser

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
#### Description

fix #7551

#### Checklist

 - [x] I have updated tests where applicable.
 - [x] I have added an entry to the CHANGELOG.

body:
@mhils I can contribute option like `--dangerous-no-password`

do u think should I do it ? 

we have use case like... using `mitmproxy` to intercept request internally (testing environment)

Adding `token` is workaround, but it require some unnecessary documentation to tell them to access.

And people might missed those document.

I feel like we should provide an option, but keep having password as a default behavior

@chaintng: I don't think what you describes qualifies as a good use case / reasonable justification. You have to share the URL somewhere, and that URL might as well include a token parameter. If you care so much about convenience, you can place a reverse proxy in front of the web ui. But I don't want the added complexity in mitmproxy for no good reason. :)
